title: EM induction - rectangular loop HxW at constant v

content.question: A rectangular loop is made by bending a resistive wire of resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> and connecting the ends of the wire together. The wire loop has height <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math> and horizontal width <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>W</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. At the instant shown, the loop is moving to the right and entering a region of uniform magnetic field <math alttext="vector B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>. The field is directed into the plane of the figure and occupies the region defined by <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to 3 W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>W</mi></math> and <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to y, which is less than or equal to 3 H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>H</mi></math> in an <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-coordinate system. An external force is exerted on the loop, as necessary, in order to keep the loop moving at a constant speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> in the positive <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction (toward the right). Gravitational forces are negligible. (a)i. Derive an expression for the magnitude of the external force exerted on the loop when the loop is at the position shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math>, <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>W</mi></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math>, <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

frqParts.text: A rectangular loop is made by bending a resistive wire of resistance <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> and connecting the ends of the wire together. The wire loop has height <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math> and horizontal width <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>W</mi></math>, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. At the instant shown, the loop is moving to the right and entering a region of uniform magnetic field <math alttext="vector B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>. The field is directed into the plane of the figure and occupies the region defined by <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to 3 W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>W</mi></math> and <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to y, which is less than or equal to 3 H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>H</mi></math> in an <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-coordinate system. An external force is exerted on the loop, as necessary, in order to keep the loop moving at a constant speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> in the positive <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-direction (toward the right). Gravitational forces are negligible. (a)i. Derive an expression for the magnitude of the external force exerted on the loop when the loop is at the position shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math>, <math alttext="H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>H</mi></math>, <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>W</mi></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math>, <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

ii. On the axes in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, sketch a graph of the magnitude of the magnetic flux <math alttext="phi sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mi>B</mi></msub></math> through the loop as a function of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>, where is the position of the leading edge (right side) of the loop. <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> corresponds to the position at which the right side of the loop just enters the field region. On the vertical axis, label any maxima or minima for the flux magnitude.Note: if a minimum is zero, you do NOT need to add a label for it.

The loop moves to the right through the magnetic field region at a constant velocity <math alttext="vector v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mover><mi>v</mi><mo>→</mo></mover></math>. In Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, the loop is shown at three locations <math alttext="uppercase X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>, <math alttext="uppercase Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, and <math alttext="uppercase Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math>, as it moves through the field.At location <math alttext="uppercase X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>, less than half of the loop area is inside the field region.At location <math alttext="uppercase Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math>, more than half of the loop area is inside the field region.(b) Rank the magnitudes <math alttext="I sub uppercase X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="I sub uppercase Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></msub></math>, and <math alttext="I sub uppercase Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></msub></math> of the induced currents in the loop when it is at positions <math alttext="uppercase X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math>, <math alttext="uppercase Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, and <math alttext="uppercase Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></math>, respectively. Use “<math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>” for the greatest magnitude, “<math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>” for the next greatest magnitude, and so on. If any currents have the same magnitude, use the same number for their ranking._____<math alttext="I sub uppercase X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mi>I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.4em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></math>_____<math alttext="I sub uppercase Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mi>I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></msub><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace></math>_____<math alttext="I sub uppercase Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msub><mi>I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Z</mi></msub></math>Justify your ranking using physics principles.

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
